Fresco painting was a major art form in the Minoan era of art made in ancient Crete, around 2000 to 1450 BC. The Minoan civilization, named after the legendary King Minos, was centered on the island of Crete and thrived during the Bronze Age. Fresco painting, a technique where pigments are applied on fresh lime plaster, allowing the colors to fuse with the plaster as it hardens, was extensively used in Minoan architecture.

One of the most famous examples of Minoan fresco painting is the "Palace of Knossos," discovered by archaeologist Sir Arthur Evans. The palace walls were adorned with intricate frescoes depicting various scenes from daily life, religious rituals, and natural motifs such as flowers, plants, and animals. Notable subjects include the "Bull-leaping" frescoes, which portray acrobatic feats involving bulls, reflecting the significance of these animals in Minoan culture.

These frescoes not only showcase the artistic skills of the Minoans but also provide valuable insights into their society, beliefs, and interactions with nature. The use of vibrant colors and detailed imagery in Minoan frescoes has had a lasting impact on the study of ancient art and continues to captivate audiences today.
